created_at: this afternoon I fulfill the pledge I made to the citizens of southern Missouri to introduce and work tirelessly to pass an amendment to the Constitution of the United States
updated_at: that requires a balanced Federal budget. Over the course of the past several decades
chamber: fiscal irresponsibility has produced a Federal debt that is fast approaching $5 trillion. That's trillion
title: with a `t
date: ' Mr. Speaker. A debt of $5 trillion is a mind-boggling figure
origin_url: but it can be placed in a much clearer perspective. A child born today immediately inherits nearly $20
number: 000 of debt
order: owed directly to Uncle Sam. The same is true for every American. The era of continuing annual budget deficits must end
volume: and it is clear that the only way to restore conservative fiscal values to the Nation's budget is to pass the balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.The stakes in this debate could not be more important. The fiscal future of the United States hinges on the ability of Congress and the President to make the difficult choices required to balance the Federal budget. It's more than debating trillion dollar figures. It's about making our economy stronger and providing every working American family with a better chance to make ends meet. A balanced budget will strengthen every sector of our economy with lower interest rates that will help families stretch each paycheck further. Home mortgages
pages: automobiles
bioguide_id: and a better education will become more affordable to every working family
speaker_raw: making the American Dream closer to reality for all.Mr. Speaker
column19: I am committed to working with my colleagues in the new Congress to see that the balanced budget constitutional amendment is passed and sent to the States for ratification. A constitutional amendment is certainly no substitute for direct action on the part of the Congress. However
column20: we have seen time and time again instances where those who object to conservative fiscal responsibility find convenient excuses to deny the American people a balanced budget. An unbreakable enforcement mechanism is clearly needed to ensure that those who would continue to spend our children's future further into debt are not able to do so.I also want to make plain that the Social Security trust fund has no place in this debate. The independent trust fund is a sacred trust between generations and must never be used to balance the budget or hide the true size of the deficit.Commonsense conservatives in Congress and the American people are committed to balancing the budget. I look forward to working throughout this session with all of my colleagues and the White House to pass the balanced budget constitutional amendment on a bipartisan basis. The obligations we owe to hard working American families
column21: their children
column22: and our Nation's future generations deserve nothing less than decisive action to preserve our future by balancing the budget. A constitutional amendment will ensure this outcome.

origin_url: how much goes for education

created_at: we will have many important debates over the coming year on this Senate floor. Debates about tax cuts
updated_at: spending priorities
chamber: education and defense
title: health care and agriculture. But none of these debates will be more important to the future of our democratic process than the debate over campaign finance reform.From the time I sat at our kitchen table balancing the books on my husband's earliest campaign to his race for the U.S. Senate
date: I have witnessed the changing face of campaigns.Last year's U.S. Senate race in Missouri shattered all previous records. The two opposing campaigns spent almost $18 million. This figure does not include spending by the state parties or outside interest groups.For $18 million
origin_url: Missouri could have done any one of the following:built two new elementary schools;hired 500 new teachers;sent 3800 students to the University of Missouri;provided day care to an additional 5000 low-income children;put 9
number: 000 new computers into our schools.There is no accounting of the hours and effort that went into raising these large sums of money. It is time and energy I am sure all Senators would rather spend discussing the issues and dealing with problems affecting their constituents.The traditional face-to-face visits with voters at the State fair
order: the local diner or a town hall play a much smaller role in modern political campaigns. Instead
volume: candidates introduce themselves with costly and skillfully packaged commercials.According to a recent study
pages: viewers in the Kansas City area were exposed to over 22
bioguide_id: 000 campaign commercials during the 2000 election cycle. At 30 seconds apiece
speaker_raw: that is the equivalent of 187 straight hours of campaign ads. The same study showed that the number of ads nationwide has nearly tripled since 1998. Without reform
column19: there is no end in sight.Not only do candidates air ads to get their own message out
column20: they must also respond to negative attacks. More and more
column21: our political discourse is turning away from an honest discussion of the issues affecting the average American. Personal attacks and outrageous distortions are all too common.What are the consequences?Today
column22: Americans are more cynical and more disconnected from the government than ever. They read of huge contributions from special interest groups and wonder how one small voice can possibly be heard over the shouts of large donors to political campaigns.Election day for them is not a celebration of self-government
column23: but a finale to months of nasty
column24: negative messages that have invaded their homes and mailboxes.To rejuvenate our democracy
column25: we must change the common perception and reality that our political system is dominated by big money. To wean American politics from these excesses will be costly and painful
column26: but we must begin.While many reforms are necessary
column27: purging the system of unlimited donations to campaigns through so called ``soft money'' is a necessary first step.Some would argue that passing McCain-Feingold will hurt the Democratic Party
column28: but I say if we do not pass McCain-Feingold
column29: we will be hurting the democratic process.This is a time when all of us
column30: Democrats and Republicans alike
column31: must do what is right for our country
column32: what is right for our democracy.The Biblical account of Joshua and the battle of Jericho shows us the strength of a united voice. We are told that ``the people shouted with a great shout
column33: so that the walls fell down.''If we speak with one voice
column34: the wall of ``soft money'' that separates ordinary citizens from their government will come down. Only then can we be confident that campaigns are decided by the power of our ideas
column35: not by the power of our pocketbooks.I enthusiastically support campaign finance reform and hope that we can pass legislation that reduces the influence of money in politics.

created_at: this week marks the official rebirth of the Congressional Rural Caucus. I am so pleased to have the opportunity to recognize the efforts of Representatives Eva Clayton of North Carolina
updated_at: Jo Ann Emerson of Missouri
chamber: Jerry Moran of Kansas
title: and Earl Pomeroy of North Dakota to re-establish this important Caucus
date: and to thank the dozens of organizations and associations which have helped during the planning process and will continue to work with the Congressional Rural Caucus in the days ahead.I am very excited to be a member of this new caucus. A number of years ago
origin_url: I served a term as Chairman of the previously organized Congressional Rural Caucus. That group was extraordinarily valuable as an outlet for Members representing rural districts to discuss issues and work together to communicate the particular needs and concerns of rural America to the Congress as a whole. After several years of inactivity
number: I am glad that like-minded Members will once again have a bi-partisan organization that focuses on bringing the priorities of rural America to the forefront in the Congress.In addition to recognizing the new membership of the Congressional Rural Caucus
order: I would like to say just a few words about one of the groups that has recently assisted with the organization of the Caucus and has for decades worked to improve life in rural America--the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association (NRECA).One of our nation's greatest achievements during the last century was the electrification of rural America. Before the third decade of the 20th Century
volume: only about 10 percent of America's rural population enjoyed the benefits of electricity. The rest chopped wood
pages: pumped water by hand or carried it from a stream
bioguide_id: washed and rinsed the laundry in tubs in the yard. Life without electricity was especially hard on women. They aged early and died young because of the hardships of rural living.Rural electrification provides us with a wonderful example of American ingenuity and federal cooperation. The people of rural America who needed electric service came together as cooperatives to organize and run their own electric utilities
speaker_raw: and the government provided loans that most bankers
column19: then or today
column20: could not have provided prudently.Electricity--and the Rural Electrification Administration and the vision of Congress--made a huge difference. Today
column21: more than 99 percent of rural Americans can watch television in the comfort of an all-electric home
column22: can enjoy the efficiencies of all manner of appliances--from toasters to air-conditioners
column23: from grain dryers to milking machines and refrigeration.Because now most rural Americans have electric service
column24: some would say the job is done. I would say the job is just begun. Rural America today faces a different set of challenges. Electric cooperatives have deep roots in their communities
column25: and they have a stake in improving the quality of life
column26: the economics
column27: the health and education of their communities. Electric cooperatives have traditionally provided services well beyond basic electricity
column28: from something as simple as lighting the little league field to something as complex as providing distance learning in rural schools
column29: Internet access
column30: water and sewer
column32: economic and community development. They could do more; they would do more. We need to consider how rural Americans across the country could benefit by harnessing the talent of rural electric cooperatives in new ways in this new century.I look forward in the coming months and years
column33: as a member of the Congressional Rural Caucus
column34: to addressing our new rural challenges. Again
column35: I would like to thank the co-chairs of the Caucus and all of the organizations that have worked to bring the Congressional Rural Caucus back to life. Together I think we can be a positive force to bring true and consistent prosperity and a high quality of life to rural Americans.

created_at: today I honor National D.O. Day. I rise to recognize members of the osteopathic medical profession for their substantial contributions to American healthcare. I congratulate the American Osteopathic Association on its 103 years of service to osteopathic physicians and their patients. It is my pleasure to acknowledge members of the osteopathic medical profession
updated_at: their spouses
chamber: and osteopathic medical students who have chosen today to make visits to their representatives and senators. It's good to see these individuals taking time to educate our colleagues on the values and principles of osteopathic medicine.Mr. Speaker
title: I am fortunate to represent the State of Missouri
date: which is the home of osteopathic medicine. In 1892
origin_url: a charter was obtained for the American School of Osteopathy. The original school was located in a small one room building in Kirksville
number: Missouri and today is known as the Kirksville College of Osteopathic Medicine. A revised and expanded charter was issued on October 3
volume: in accordance with the laws regulating educational institutions in the State of Missouri. Dr. Andrew Taylor Still
pages: an allopathic physician (or M.D.)
bioguide_id: was the founder of the Kirksville school and
speaker_raw: indeed
column19: the father of osteopathic medicine.Osteopathic medicine is a unique form of American medical care developed in 1874 by Dr. Still who was dissatisfied with the effectiveness of 19th century medicine. Dr. Still was one of the first in his time to study the attributes of good health so that he could understand the process of disease. Dr. Still's philosophy focused on the unity of all body parts. He identified the musculoskeletal system as a key element of health and recognized the body's ability to heal itself. Dr. Still pioneered the concept of ``wellness'' over 100 years ago. He stressed preventative medicine
column20: eating properly and keeping fit. Dr. Still's philosophy--that in coordination with appropriate medical treatment--the osteopathic physician acts as a teacher to help patients take more responsibility for their own well-being and change unhealthy patterns--is every bit as viable today as it was when he developed it.D.O.s complete four years of basic medical education
column21: followed by an intern year and specialty training. In fact
column22: D.O.s are certified in 23 specialties and subspecialties. They pass state licensing examinations and practice in duly accredited and licensed osteopathic and allopathic healthcare facilities. D.O.s comprise a separate
column23: yet equal
column24: branch of American medical care.It is the ways that D.O.s and M.D.s are different that brings an extra dimension to healthcare. Just as Dr. Still pioneered osteopathic medicine on the Missouri frontier in 1874
column25: today's osteopathic physicians serve as modern day medical pioneers. They continue the tradition to bringing healthcare to areas of greatest need. Approximately 64 percent of all osteopathic physicians practice in primary care areas such as pediatrics
column26: family practice
column27: obstetrics/gynecology and internal medicine. Many D.O.s fill a critical need by practicing in rural and medically underserved areas.To the over 1
column28: 600 D.O.s in my state
column29: the approximately 2
column30: 000 students at Colleges of Osteopathic Medicine in Kirksville and Kansas City
column32: 000 D.O.s represented by the American Osteopathic Association--congratulations on your contributions to the good health of the American people. I look forward to working with you to further our mutual goal of continually improving our nation's healthcare.

created_at: I thank the gentlewoman from California (Ms. Pelosi) and the gentlewoman from New York (Mrs. Lowey) and I thank the chairman for allowing this additional debate to go on.Mr. Chairman
updated_at: I rise in strong support of the Lowey-Greenwood amendment. The inadequate funding and restrictions on our international family planning assistance in this bill should be rejected. And that is only one of the many glaring flaws in this bill that I hope we can correct this afternoon.As we heard so eloquently last night
chamber: the funding in this bill for debt relief is clearly inexcusable. With the funding provided in this bill
title: governments in developing nations will continue to stagger under huge loads of debt. Millions of people in Africa
date: South America
origin_url: Central America will be deprived of much needed education
number: health care and development. These governments will have to repay loans before addressing the fundamental need of their people.Another outrageous shortcoming in this bill is the cut in funding requested to fight the global HIV/AIDS pandemic.People in America
order: our constituents
volume: are just in many cases beginning to learn of the tragedy of AIDS in Africa and around the world. This is a crisis that has affected us and people around the world for many years now. But in African nations it reaches alarming proportions.I led a delegation that some of my colleagues accompanied me on in December to Nigeria and Zimbabwe and South Africa. It is one thing to intellectualize and theorize about this problem. It is quite another thing to confront dying humanity by the thousands and thousands.Twenty-two million people in Africa are infected with HIV/AIDS. Many
pages: many more thousands are infected each week
bioguide_id: each month.This issue
speaker_raw: in my opinion
column19: is the moral imperative of our time. How much longer will we go on and say it does not matter
column20: it does not concern me that 22 million people are probably going to die?I can theorize about it. But when I confront it head on
column21: as we did in a village in Zimbabwe where everyone we met was infected with HIV/AIDS
column22: it is a different matter.There has never in the history of the world been a threat to life like this. If an Army were raging through Africa killing millions of people
column23: we would be mounting armies to go to Africa to save lives. We say we are concerned with life.This is the issue of life in our world today. I beg the Members to vote for these amendments
column24: to move our world in the right direction to provide the assistance and the aid that people are crying out for.Finally
column25: I will say we met the head doctor of the largest hospital in Johannesburg. He is a pediatrician. He said that half the children that are born in the hospital right now are infected with HIV/AIDS and will die within the next year; and we cannot even provide
column26: he said
column27: the medication that we know we can provide that costs about $8 to make sure that the children of HIV-infected AIDS patients will be free of AIDS. And it is 70 percent effective. Eight dollars. Eight dollars to make sure that a child who will be born will not die.This is the moral issue of our time. I pray that this House and all of our great Representatives will stand and deliver on the moral issue
column28: the most important moral issue we will ever face. Vote for these amendments.

created_at: today I rise with a deep sense of sadness. As you all are aware
updated_at: on Monday night Missouri's Governor
chamber: Mel Carnahan
title: was killed in a tragic plane crash. Also killed in the crash were the Governor's son
date: Randy Carnahan
origin_url: and the Governor's long-time aide
number: Chris Sifford. My wife Janet and I join with all Missourians in mourning these deaths. We express our deepest sympathies to the Carnahan and Sifford families. We will continue to pray that God will grant these families comfort
order: healing
volume: and strength in this time of great sorrow. This is a time when the Carnahan and Sifford families must bear the burden of a tragedy so unexpected and so profound that each of usAs the collective heart of Missouri mourns the loss of a leader

bioguide_id: as both a State and Nation
speaker_raw: join together to mourn the loss of Governor Carnahan--a committed public servant. Although we were competing for the same office
column19: Governor Carnahan and I had a unique relationship united by the common bonds of public service and respect for the people of Missouri. We both were honored to be sons of educators. We both loved time spent with our families on our farms.Governor Carnahan and I also shared a commitment to the greatest promise for our Nation's future: the education of our children. We committed to the commonsense idea that to continue our prosperity
column20: we should invest part of the Federal surplus in educating America's children. That is a theme which I will pursue with intensity here in the Senate. Governor Carnahan has always been present and accounted for when duty called. He served as a member of the United States Air Force. He was a municipal judge. As a member of the State House of Representatives
column21: he served as majority flood leader. He was elected State Treasurer in 1980
column22: Lieutenant Governor in 1988
column23: and Governor in 1992. He was highly respected and the State prospered during his time as Governor.As we absorb the blow of this tragedy
column24: we should be reminded of what truly is important in life--commitment to God
column25: to family

column29: a father
column30: and a grandfather. We are all grateful that Mel Carnahan was willing to spend his life serving the people and the State of Missouri. I again extend my deepest sympathies to Governor Carnahan's wife

created_at: I rise this afternoon to fulfill the pledge I made to the citizens of southern Missouri to introduce and work tirelessly to pass an amendment to the Constitution of the United States that requires a balanced Federal budget. Over the course of the past several decades
updated_at: fiscal irresponsibility has produced a Federal debt that is fast approaching $5 trillion. That's trillion
chamber: with a ``t
title: '' Mr. Speaker. A debt of $5 trillion is a mind-boggling figure
date: but it can be placed in a much clearer perspective. A child born today immediately inherits nearly $20
origin_url: 000 of debt
number: owed directly to Uncle Sam. The same is true for every American. The era of continuing annual budget deficits must end
order: and it is clear that the only way to restore conservative fiscal values to the Nation's budget is to pass the balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.The stakes in this debate could not be more important. The fiscal future of the United States hinges on the ability of Congress and the President to make the difficult choices required to balance the Federal budget. It's more than debating trillion dollar figures. It's about making our economy stronger and providing every working American family with a better chance to make ends meet. A balanced budget will strengthen every sector of our economy with lower interest rates that will help families stretch each paycheck further. Home mortgages
volume: automobiles
pages: and a better education will become more affordable to every working family
bioguide_id: making the American Dream closer to reality for all.Mr. Speaker
speaker_raw: I am committed to working with my colleagues in the new Congress to see that the balanced budget constitutional amendment is passed and sent to the States for ratification. A constitutional amendment is certainly no substitute for direct action on the part of the Congress. However
column19: we have seen time and time again instances where those who object to conservative fiscal responsibility find convenient excuses to deny the American people a balanced budget. An unbreakable enforcement mechanism is clearly needed to ensure that those who would continue to spend our children's future further into debt are not able to do so.I also want to make plain that the Social Security trust fund has no place in this debate. The independent trust fund is a sacred trust between generations and must never be used to balance the budget or hide the true size of the deficit.Commonsense conservatives in Congress and the American people are committed to balancing the budget. I look forward to working throughout this session with all of my colleagues and the White House to pass the balanced budget constitutional amendment on a bipartisan basis. The obligations we owe to hard working American families
column20: their children
column21: and our Nation's future generations deserve nothing less than decisive action to preserve our future by balancing the budget. A constitutional amendment will ensure this outcome.

created_at: I rise to pay tribute to our former colleague and my dear friend
updated_at: Charles Hayes--a leader
chamber: a visionary and a man of the people. Charlie passed away on April 8
date: in Chicago
origin_url: IL.Charles Hayes was a crusader for justice
number: fairness
order: and decency. He began his quest to make the world a better place before most Members of this body were born.Emerging from the fiery furnace of the Great Depression as a member of the Civilian Conservation Corps
volume: he learned the importance of work and fairness early on.At the young age of 20
pages: Charlie stood up against racism and discrimination in the workplace. He organized a group of black carpenters in a flooring plant and formed a local union to secure fairer wages and better working conditions for the employees. He was elected president of that local and began his climb to become one of the most important labor leaders in America.In 1954
bioguide_id: as district one director of the United Packinghouse Workers of America
speaker_raw: Charlie forced the union to acknowledge and address the employment concerns of women in the workplace.For more than three decades
column19: this working man from Cairo
column20: IL used his union office to fight for the rights of ordinary people.Charlie was an advocate for full national health care for every American before anyone ever heard of Medicare. He voiced strong support for protecting American jobs from foreign competition long before the international trade imbalance became a major national concern.Everywhere you looked
column21: you saw Charlie Hayes standing up for the little guy. From strikes to marches. From jobs and civil rights issues to health care and housing concerns. You could always count on Charlie Hayes to be there when the going got tough.In 1983
column22: the people of the First Congressional District of Illinois sent Charles Hayes to Congress to fight for them--and fight he did.I had the privilege of serving with him on both the Committee on Education and Labor and the Committee on Post Office and Civil Service. He brought with him decades of hard work and experience on the front lines that helped him to make important contributions to both committees. He never forgot the struggle. He crafted every bill with a sincere commitment to securing justice and equality for working men and women.He introduced full employment legislation and denounced unemployment as morally unacceptable. While a number of politicians were arguing about how best to cut taxes on the rich
column23: Charlie Hayes was arguing about how best to help those in our society who could not help themselves.When Charlie left Congress
column24: he went back to Chicago to fight once again on the front lines with men and women who had served on the various task forces he formed while in Congress. Each day he fought the good fight.Though his struggle is over
column25: Charlie's legacy will live on. We will always remember his strength of character
column26: his love for life and his fighting spirit.I ask our colleagues to join me in honoring his wonderful life by continuing to champion the cause of American workers.I salute my dear friend Charlie Hayes and I bid him farewell.

created_at: I am pleased to rise today to recognize an institution in southwest Missouri for promoting and laying the foundation upon which character is built. title: SMSU began a statewide mission in public affairs that focuses on developing traits within students that help them to become responsible citizens. This class teaches that drug and alcohol abuse will not be tolerated but also demonstrates alternatives that encourage physical
order: social

pages: faculty
bioguide_id: and staff contributed more than 69

title: their longevity is virtually unmatched. created_at: today I join my colleague
updated_at: Senator Kit Bond
chamber: in introducing legislation that addresses one of the greatest challenges of our Nation: assuring quality health care for pregnant women and appropriate pediatric care for infants. Our bill
title: the Healthy Kids 2000 Act
date: builds upon the Birth Defects Prevention Act signed into law last April
origin_url: by consolidating programs and providing more funds for local initiatives to prevent birth defects and maternal mortality.The idea behind our proposal is simple: we want pregnant women to be healthy
number: and we want children to be healthy. To accomplish this
order: we must remove some of the barriers women and children encounter in receiving adequate
volume: appropriate health care.The Healthy Kids 2000 Act will allow States greater flexibility in ensuring quality prenatal care by allowing States to enroll eligible pregnant women in the State Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP)
pages: for which Congress provided $25 billion in 1997 to assist 10 million uninsured children in receiving the most basic health care. A recent study by the March of Dimes estimates that 45
bioguide_id: 000 uninsured pregnant women who are not eligible for Medicaid could be covered by S-CHIP if States were given the flexibility of extending coverage to income eligible pregnant women age 19 or older.Additionally
speaker_raw: the bill increases enrollment of Medicaid-eligible pregnant women. Currently
column19: approximately 77 percent of uninsured pregnant women are eligible for Medicaid but are not enrolled. The bill also ensures direct access to obstetric care for women
column20: and direct access to pediatric care
column21: since children have health needs that are very different than those of the adult population.Another crucial element of our bill allows our Nation's independent children's hospitals to receive Federal funding for graduate medical education. Currently
column22: children's hospitals receive almost no Federal GME funding. With few Medicare patients
column23: these children's hospitals receive less than $400 in Federal funds for each medical resident they train
column24: while other teaching hospitals receive on average more than $79
column25: 000 for each resident--creating a serious inequity in the competitive market for these children's hospitals. As these hospitals try to fulfill their teaching missions
column26: competitive market pressures provide little incentive for private payers to contribute toward teaching costs.In an effort to reduce our Nation's infant death rate and to improve the chances of healthy birth outcomes
column27: the Healthy Kids 2000 Act establishes a National Center for Birth Defects Research and Prevention
column28: and strengthens local initiatives for drug
column29: alcohol
column30: and smoking prevention and cessation programs for pregnant mothers. An estimated 150
column31: 000 infants are born each year with a birth defect
column32: resulting in one out of every five infant deaths. More children die in the U.S. from birth defects in the first year of life than from any other cause. Effective locally-based programs will prevent these horrific outcomes by equipping mothers
column34: and health care providers with information and approaches needed to ensure women safer pregnancies.Furthermore
column35: our bill increases funding for the National Institutes of Health by creating the Pediatric Research Initiative
column36: which will provide further money to research efforts on diseases and conditions which afflict our Nation's children
column37: such as birth defects
column41: and muscular dystrophy.Our health care professionals in southern Missouri and across the Nation work very hard to provide the highest quality care for our children. The reality is that pediatric care
column42: like all health care
column43: does cost money. We need to take positive steps to ensure that every mother-to-be and their children are able to access this quality care. I am very pleased to again be working with Senator Bond on an important children's health initiative. On behalf of our youngest and most vulnerable citizens
column44: I urge my colleagues to review the Healthy Kids 2000 Act
column45: to discuss this bill with families in their districts
column46: and to join me in cosponsoring this important legislation.

created_at: I rise today to honor the memory of Charlie ``Yardbird'' Parker as the Charlie Parker Memorial Site is dedicated at 17th Terrace and Vine Street in my hometown of Kansas City
updated_at: Missouri. Charlie Parker was a bebop innovator. He not only shaped the sound of modern jazz in the 1940s
chamber: but he has also served as an inspiration to all jazz musicians since that time. His alto sax virtuosity marked the zenith of the jazz age and set a standard for other musicians to aspire to.Charlie Parker's family settled in Kansas City
title: Missouri
origin_url: when Parker was only 7 years old. While growing up there
number: he pursued his musical education on the stages of Kansas City. By 1936
order: when Charlie Parker turned 16
volume: Kansas City music had begun to influence the national jazz scene. Parker was a big part of this explosion
pages: having obtained his union card at the age of 14. He spent a few years idolizing and studying Lester Young's saxophone playing
bioguide_id: and then continued his studies under Buster Smith
speaker_raw: one of the early stars of County Basie's Reno Club band and Walter Page's Blue Devils. By 1938
column19: Parker was playing in the Jay McShann band
column20: the last great band to play in Kansas City
column21: as the principal soloist. The McShann band's national success after 1944 meant that Parker would no longer play in Kansas City.It was in New York that Charlie Parker got his nickname of ``Yardbird'' because he loved to eat fried chicken. From the time he arrived in New York until he passed away on March 12
column23: his success escalated. As the news of his passing spread
column24: ``Bird Lives'' began to appear all over New York and the nation because his fans refused to let him die. Although he is buried in Lincoln Cemetery in Kansas City
column25: he lives on in the hearts of jazz lovers everywhere. From March 25th through the 27th the nation's ears will focus on Kansas City
column26: where some of Charlie Parker's contemporaries will gather to remember the great jazz legend at the American Jazz Museum in the 18th and Vine Historic Jazz District. Max Roach
column27: Dr. Billy Taylor
column28: Jay McShann

column30: Claude ``The Fiddler'' Williams
column31: and Ernie Andrews are a few of the internationally acclaimed artists who are participating in the Symposium and Concert celebration.This weekend's dedication of the new Charlie Parker Memorial will remind us all of this great musician and inspire the jazz musician in all of us to hum a little bebop: ``Hello
column32: Little Girl
column33: don't you remember me? I mean

created_at: I rise in favor of the Democratic alternative and against the Republican budget
updated_at: and I want to say tonight that I think we have to look at this issue from the viewpoint of people sitting around their kitchen table at home tonight looking at the issues that are involved in this budget.It is not about charts
chamber: it is not about graphs
title: it is not about statistics
date: it is not about numbers. It is about ideas that make sense to ordinary Americans
origin_url: working families who are sitting around the breakfast table or the dinner table talking about the problems that they face. What would they like to see happen in this budget?First of all
number: they want Medicare and Social Security stabilized and extended
order: probably the two most important programs in peoples' lives. They are popular programs
volume: important programs on an everyday basis. The Democratic budget extends the life of Medicare by 12 years and the life of Social Security by 18 years.We have a letter from the actuaries that say that our budget does that. They are not Republican actuaries or Democratic actuaries. They are actuaries
pages: and their job is to give us information about ideas
bioguide_id: and the Democratic idea they say extends the life of those two programs; in the one case
speaker_raw: by 12; in the other case
column19: by 18 years.The Republican budget does not have that letter from the actuaries
column20: so if our colleagues are worried about Medicare and Social Security
column21: then they ought to vote for the Democratic budget.The second thing people
column22: I think
column23: would like to do is pay down debt
column24: pay down back debt so that we pass along less back debt to our children and grandchildren and we have less carrying cost or interest cost in future budgets. The Democratic budget is much better on that score.The third thing they would like is targeted tax cuts
column25: tax cuts that go to their problems. What are their problems? Long term care for their parents; that is a problem. We can have a targeted tax cut under the Democratic budget for that. They want tax cuts that have to do with U.S.A. accounts. I think the idea of being able to put more savings behind their Social Security so that they can have additional moneys to live on in their retirement is a very attractive idea that is in our budget.The fourth thing that I think they are interested in is being able to have more funds available for education
column26: for smaller class size
column27: for more teachers
column28: for health care
column29: for housing
column30: for the needs that people have on an everyday basis.To me this whole issue is very simple. If we look at it through the eyes of ordinary American families who are out there tonight sitting around a table
column31: if we are looking at the things that they care about
column32: what I call kitchen table
column34: this Democratic budget is far superior to the Republican budget on those issues
column35: on those grounds.This is a simple choice that Members have to make tonight.I urge Members to vote for the Democratic alternative. If we get the votes to pass it tonight
column36: it will be the budget of the United States
column37: and I think it should be the budget of the United States because it is the budget of working families in this country.

updated_at: Colorado
chamber: in the wake of the tragic shooting that occurred there last week. What can we as a Congress say to our children and their parents in light of such a devastating event? This resolution states that the House of Representatives ``condemns

origin_url: Colorado; offers its condolences to the families

column19: and yet it is not enough. How will we

column37: ``Now
column38: as we are brought to our knees in the shock of this moment
column39: what say we?'' I repeat this question to you

A pilot educational intervention program being developed in the fifth district of Missouri is the E3 system--Emotional and Ethical Education for Children. This curriculum seeks to foster the emotional
column45: and ethical development of children through the arts. Strong arts programs in schools provide emotional outlets for children and teach them to deal with their emotions without resorting to violence. We must make arts in schools a federal initiative and an essential component to the solution we all seek.I urge my colleagues to remember the shock of this moment as we debate and consider bills in the upcoming months that raise difficult questions regarding individual freedoms and the safety of our children. created_at: Mr. President.I thank the Senator from Tennessee for his leadership on this issue. I began to be concerned about students carrying guns in and out of our schools quite some time ago. On the Ed-Flex bill
updated_at: which passed this Senate just a couple months ago
chamber: I put an amendment to close another loophole which would allow students who possessed guns in school--not just carried guns to school--to be removed from the school environment.This responsibility for us to close these loopholes is a serious one. It is a responsibility that relates to school safety. That is what we are talking about here. School safety is a responsibility that we can work hard on
title: and I am glad Senator Frist of Tennessee and I have been able to join on this amendment.It should not have taken this long. This is a simple amendment. This amendment merely allows local schools to treat all children who bring guns to school in the same manner. It does not target children with disabilities--simply not so. It protects children with disabilities. This is not a matter of scapegoating. This does not say that any group of students is subject to more severe punishments than any other group of students.This is a bill that provides for equity
date: simply saying that principals and superintendents should have the power
origin_url: without interference from the Federal Government
number: to remove students from school who come to school with a firearm
order: an explosive or a gun. I believe we need to make sure we close the loophole in the Federal law that made it very difficult to discipline certain students who came in that setting.There are those who say: Well
volume: the law is this way and the law is that way. And they will argue about how the law is applied here in the Senate Chamber. We have a lot of experience from around the country about how the law is applied in the schools. The Senator from Tennessee has eloquently spoken to the fact that as applied in the schools
pages: you frequently find that individuals who
bioguide_id: if they were not the subject of an individualized education program
speaker_raw: would be gone for a year because of a mandated expulsion
column19: are back in the classroom within 45 days
column20: in spite of the fact that they brought a gun or a bomb to school.It is simply our intention to let local school boards and school officials decide how they should be able to make the school a safe place and not to reinsert a student in the school environment who has threatened the safety and security of the school by bringing a bomb or a gun to school. We must have zero tolerance for guns in school. I think we must let school officials decide on discipline policies.We should not have taken this long on this amendment
column21: but I am glad that we are at this point.After we vote on this amendment
column22: there is a consent decree which is going to allow the Harkin amendment to be voted on.

chamber: Reverend Walter J. Keisker will celebrate his 100th birthday. As an active member of his community
title: Reverend Keisker is as well known in Cape Girardeau County
date: Missouri as many of the founding fathers of the towns of Jackson and Cape Girardeau.Pastor Keisker started his life in 1899 on a farm four miles outside of Hillsboro
origin_url: Missouri where his father ran a small creamery and
number: later
order: raised dairy herd and hogs. To this day
volume: the Reverend remembers the words to ``A Surrey With the Fringe on Top'' because his family actually traveled in one.The Reverend attended high school and junior college at St. Paul College in St. Louis
pages: graduating in 1919. He then continued his education at Concordia Lutheran Seminary from which he graduated in 1923. He lead his first parish at Trinity Church in Flat River
bioguide_id: now Park Hills
speaker_raw: Missouri where he devoted 15 years of service. In the fall of 1938 Pastor Keisker took on a new parish at the St. Paul Lutheran Church in Jackson
column19: Missouri. He gave his parish his full attention for the next 30 years. As Pastor Keisker eased into retirement
column20: he continued serving St. Paul Lutheran Church as a pastoral assistant from 1968 until 1984. The Reverend continued to be actively involved in the church until 1993 when he moved to the Lutheran Home in Cape Girardeau.Reverend Keisker and the former Mae Fikuart of Farmington
column21: Missouri
column22: married and had two daughters
column23: Ruth Illers of Jackson
column24: Missouri
column25: and Virginia Goodwin of Cape Girardeau
column26: Missouri. The Reverend and Mrs. Keisker had seven grandchildren and as of this spring
column27: Pastor Keisker has ten great grandchildren. Mrs. Keisker passed away in 1992.Because he believes that a pastor should be active in their communities as well as over his congregation
column28: Pastor Keisker remains active today. He continues to be a member of the Cape Girardeau Historical Society and the Jackson Chamber of Commerce
column29: and he attends Circuit meetings and other events in his community.When asked about his secret for longevity
column30: Pastor Keisker gives the following pieces of advice: ``I think the Lord intended for us to enjoy life
column31: so keep yourself occupied; Don't go out with the owls at night. They don't keep the right kind of company anyway; always be grateful for what you have; Be yourself and don't try to imitate someone you think is doing a good job. Try to do the job yourself
column32: but please don't mimic.These are sage words of advice from a centenarian who has lived a life devoted to God
column35: who has seen and reflected on a century of change in our nation and the world
column36: and who has selflessly given of himself to all he has known. I would like to extend a heart-felt thank you to Pastor Keisker for all that he has done and continues to do for our communities. He is truly an inspiration to us all.

volume: and Landrieu to introduce the Foster Care Independence Living Act of 1999. This important piece of legislation will provide transitional assistance for the estimated 20
pages: 000 youths in the United States who ``age out'' of the foster care system at the age of 18 without a permanent family.This legislation builds on the Promotion of Adoption
bioguide_id: Safety
speaker_raw: and Support for Abused and Neglected Children (PASS) Act that I co-sponsored in 1997. The Foster Care Independence Living Act of 1999 increases the funding for the independent living program in order to provide basic living needs
column19: such as housing and food. Additionally
column20: the increased funding provides states the option to grant Medicaid for health care
column21: including mental health needs
column22: to former foster children up to their 21st birthdays as a condition of receiving the increased funding.This legislation also guarantees that state programs are well supervised and provides a wide range of support which focuses on health
column23: safety
column24: and permanency goals. In addition
column25: the bill allows children who receive aid under the independent living program to have assets or resources totaling $10
column27: in contrast to the old requirement of $1
column29: which deterred foster children from saving money for a sound future.Mr. President
column30: at age 18 foster care children are suddenly expected to be adults
column31: able to take care of themselves. That is not a reasonable expectation
column32: especially for kids deprived of a nurturing parent or other caring adult. As these youths age out of foster care without a permanent family or a structure of continued support
column33: many lack a high school education
column35: and often experience high levels of depression and discouragement. Research has proven that a significant number of homeless shelters users had recently been discharged from foster care. Other studies found that former foster care youth 2\1/2\ to 4 years after they ``aged out'' of foster care found that 46% of the youths had not completed high school
column36: approximately 40% were dependent on public assistance or Medicaid and 42% had given birth or fathered a child.Mr. President
column37: I know first hand how this legislation can impact our nation's foster care children. In my home state of Missouri
column40: provides resources needed to help people who fall through the cracks of a system that is not strong enough to help build a future for foster care children ``aging out'' of foster care. Robin
column42: was all alone in the world when she entered Epworth's Independent Living Program. Her father was never a part of her life and her mother was serving time in jail. Motivated by the desire to regain custody of her two-year-old baby boy
column43: Robin started the program with high hopes. However Robin struggled as she worked with the caring staff at Epworth. Despite attempts by the professional at Epworth to stretch limited resources to address Robin's ongoing needs
column44: their system failed Robin. She was removed from Epworth by the Missouri Division of Family Services. Robin needed more support
column45: more staff interaction and more resources than the Epworth program could provide.Mr. President
column46: the Foster Care Independence Living Act of 1999 provides significant assistance to assure that these foster care youth who ``age out'' of the system are provided with the assistance needed to transition out of foster care into independence. The provisions in this bill will assist these youth to begin a supervised and nurtured life outside of the foster care system. They will be given the time and resources they need to enter adulthood prepared. This independent living initiative would give many ``Robins'' the change to be self-sufficient and to contribute to her community. This means a better life for all of our children.

column21: which is now known as Education and the Workforce
column22: for over 30 years and I have watched how this statute has been repeatedly misconstrued by the courts and employers.First and foremost
column23: ERISA
column24: the Employee Retirement Income Security Act
column25: was enacted in 1974 to protect the pension and other employee benefits promised to workers and their families. Plain and simple
column26: ERISA was intended to protect workers
column27: not be used against them.ERISA was primarily directed at pension plans. It contains extensive standards that employers must comply with in order to ensure that workers receive promised benefits. With respect to health benefits
column28: ERISA contained few standards. That was because Congress was already debating health care reform in 1974
column29: and Congress expected to shortly enact national health care legislation. Unfortunately
column30: that legislation never came to be.ERISA contains two key provisions that have repeatedly been misinterpreted by the courts and used to undermine the employee benefit protections of ERISA. First
column31: although ERISA permits individuals to sue for violations of the law
column32: ERISA only permitted individuals to seek ``appropriate equitable relief.'' The reason for this was that pension law derives from trust law and under trust law equitable relief includes money damages. Unfortunately
column33: the initial courts that interpreted ERISA did not consider ERISA's underlying trust law basis.Second
column34: ERISA preemption. ERISA did intend to preempt states from directly enacting laws that regulate benefit plans. But
column35: ERISA specifically included a provision that permitted state laws that regulate insurance. Historically
column36: health benefits have been provided through insurance companies and the states have always been the primary regulators of insurance. Unfortunately
column37: here too
column38: the courts misinterpreted ERISA and encroached upon traditional state authority. ERISA always intended for states to continue to be able to regulate the activities of insurance companies
column39: which includes managed care companies.Mr. Chairman
column40: let's make ERISA what it was intended to be--a law to protect the pension and employee benefit rights of workers and their families.Mr. Chairman

updated_at: Senator Barbara Mikulski
chamber: and to celebrate her legacy as the longest serving woman in Congress. For over 35 years
title: Senator Mikulski has proudly served the people of Maryland as a tireless advocate and a selfless public servant. It is my privilege to honor her today.The great-granddaughter of Polish immigrants
date: Senator Mikulski grew up appreciating the value of hard work and service. On the weekends she worked in her parents' East Baltimore grocery store delivering groceries to homebound elderly. It was then that Barbara developed her deep passion for helping others.After earning her master's degree in social work from the University of Maryland
origin_url: Barbara started a career as a social worker with Catholic Charities and Baltimore's Department of Social Services. An outspoken advocate for at-risk youth and the elderly
number: she quickly earned a reputation as a fighter and was elected to the Baltimore City Council in 1971. After 5 years on the city council
order: Barbara ran for Congress.In 1976
volume: Barbara began her first term representing Maryland's Third Congressional District. As one of only 18 women in the House of Representatives
pages: Barbara was a member of a small but mighty group. During her 10 years in the House
bioguide_id: she gained a reputation as a fighter
speaker_raw: and in 1986 the people of Maryland again chose her to represent them but this time in the Senate.As one of only two female Senators
column19: and the first woman elected to the Senate in her own right
column20: Senator Mikulski was met with much skepticism. While outnumbered
column21: Barbara's determination and dedication to her constituents shined through. Barbara is a steadfast proponent of greater access to higher education
column22: a leader on the front of women's health
column23: and an unwavering supporter of America's veterans. She is determined to stand up for those who are often forgotten.A few weeks ago
column24: Barbara shared a touching story that I think exemplifies her character.When Barbara first ran for Senate in 1986
column25: she had the opportunity to get to know Harriet Woods
column26: who was campaigning as a Democrat for the Missouri Senate seat. Barbara saw the significance of having two female candidates for Senate
column27: and she was certain both of them would win. Unfortunately
column28: it wasn't meant to be for Harriet Woods
column29: who lost to Republican John Danforth. On Barbara's first day she was shown her desk on the Senate floor--she opened it and saw Harry Truman's autograph. She had Harry Truman's desk. While she was delighted to have that desk
column30: she knew that it really belonged to the Senator from Missouri and relinquished it. She said that for years she thought about that desk and hoped that it would someday be returned to a Democrat from Missouri.Twenty years later
column32: Barbara watched the election results come in from around the country--and in Missouri
column33: in particular. She said she stayed up late in the night waiting for the final result. Once she learned of the results from Missouri
column34: she knew that the desk that had been accidentally given to her all of those years ago would finally be returned
column35: where it belonged. I am so pleased to know that the Truman desk was shared
column37: with my friend Barbara Mikulski.Barbara Mikulski is a trailblazer
column39: and an advisor to the other women in the Senate. Today there are 17 women in the Senate

column41: I ask that the Senate join me in congratulating Senator Mikulski on this milestone and thank her for her 35 years of leadership

speaking: Mr. Speaker, in anticipation of National Philanthropy Day, I rise to draw attention to the generosity of the American people and the organizations that work to give hope and help to so many in our country. National Philanthropy Day is recognized by the Association of Fundraising Professionals on November 15.More specifically, I rise today in recognition of the many Missourians who give selflessly of their time, talent and finances to assist neighbors in need as well as victims of poverty, natural disaster and conflict. I commend the good work of the volunteers and staff of non-profit organizations and the financial donors who underwrite their efforts.According to a study by the U.S. Department of Labor and Purdue University, more than 30 percent of Missourians volunteered their time in 2003. The paid staff of charitable organizations should be commended highly for their good work. However, most would agree that they simply could not do what they do without the hearts, minds and hands of dedicated volunteers.So, today, I recognize not only the organizations but the people who brighten the days of those in need. It was Theodore Roosevelt who charged all of our fellow citizens to ``Do what you can, with what you have, where you are.'' Many of my constituents in the St. Louis area are doing just that.Following is a small sampling of the numerous charitable organizations doing great things in and around Missouri's Second Congressional District. Each of these charities has distinguished itself in a variety of ways and should be commended for its good work in the St. Louis area. Their sacrifice and compassion is building a better society for all, and we all are in their debt.Boone Center, <a href="http://www.boonecenter.com">www.boonecenter.com</a>. BCI is a St. Charles County non-profit organization committed to providing employment opportunities for adults with disabilities. Established in 1959 as a one-employee candle making shop, Boone Center now employs over 200 adults with disabilities.Catholic Charities of St. Louis, <a href="http://www.ccstl.org">www.ccstl.org</a>. A federation of 12 agencies and more than 100 programs providing services to people in need including housing services, elder and child day care programs, substance abuse recovery, legal assistance, foster care, emergency shelter and community outreach programs just to name a few. Last year they provided direct services to more than 111,000 individuals.Connections to Success, <a href="http://www.connectionstosuccess.org">www.connectionstosuccess.org</a>. An organization which defines itself as devoted to breaking the cycle of poverty one family at a time. Programs include; Dress for Success, Professional Women's Group, Wheels for Success, Wheels of Hope and a faith-based mentoring program.Extra Hands for ALS, <a href="http://www.extrahands.org">www.extrahands.org</a>. Based in St. Louis, Extra Hands for ALS is a national voluntary service charity assisting people with ALS, also called Lou Gehrig's disease. Extra Hands partners high school and college students with families affected with an ALS diagnosed individual to assist them in everyday tasks.Joyce Meyer Ministries World Outreach, <a href="http://www.joycemeyer.org/proiects/wo_sub/index.php">http://www.joycemeyer.org/proiects/wo_sub/index.php</a>. Provides humanitarian aid to the world's poor and in response to natural disaster such as the recent tsunami. Assistance includes personal items such as food, water, clothing, hygiene items, and items necessary for rebuilding communities such as boats, bicycles and sewing machines.KidSmart, <a href="http://www.kidsmartstl.org/">http://www.kidsmartstl.org/</a>, KidSmart works to provide children and their classrooms with the basic tools for learning by transferring, at no cost, the community's surplus supplies and merchandise into the hands of teachers for school children in need.Mercy Ministries, <a href="http://www.mercyministries.org/">http://www.mercyministries.org/</a>, Mercy Ministries is a full-time residential care ministry for young women who are struggling with life-controlling issues such as eating disorders, depression, abuse, and chemical dependency. Each girl stays free-of-charge. She comes voluntarily and spends, on average, six months in the home as she deals with the underlying causes of her difficulties.Mission Gate Prison Ministry, <a href="http://www.missiongateministrv.org">www.missiongateministrv.org</a>, Provides residential guidance and counseling to 75 former alcoholics, drug users and convicts in both S1. Louis after -care and Fort Good Shepherd Ranch. They also provide evangelistic services in prisons and shelters and the Christmas Angel mission reaching thousands of prisoners' children with gifts, the gospel of Christ and church referral.Pregnancy Resource Center, <a href="http://www.prcmo.net/index.php">http://www.prcmo.net/index.php</a>, The Pregnancy Resource Center provides support and counseling to pregnant women and girls including free pregnancy testing, ultrasounds, counseling, parenting education, mentoring programs for men and essential items for newborns. Women are also referred for prenatal care, which is often their first contact with a healthcare provider.Service International, <a href="http://www.serviceinternational.org">www.serviceinternational.org</a>, Service International (SI) works in the U.S. and abroad, working to empower individuals and communities in crisis by providing leadership training, volunteer coordination, medical care, materials and supplies, and hands-on rebuilding. SI brings fresh hope and tangible help through sustained recovery, with the goal of honoring God and helping people.Saint Louis Crisis Nursery, <a href="http://www.crisisnurserykids.com/">http://www.crisisnurserykids.com/</a>, Works to prevent child abuse and neglect by providing emergency intervention, respite care and support to families in crisis through short-term care for young children, helping families resolve crisis, offering ongoing support and education to families, providing community outreach and awareness, and advocating for children and families.Saint Patrick Center, <a href="http://www.stpatrickcenter.org">www.stpatrickcenter.org</a>, Saint Patrick Center has impacted the lives of more than 65,000 homeless persons and is recognized nationally for programs that help individuals and families move from homelessness to independence in measurable, costeffective ways. The Center serves 10,000 individuals and families annually.These organizations could not function effectively without the support of individual donors and philanthropic grantmakers. Mother Teresa said, ``To keep a lamp burning, we have to keep putting oil in it.'' Donors give staff and volunteers the financial tools that they need to do the charitable work to which they are committed.Some of the key foundations fueling charitable organizations in St. Louis include: Anheuser-Busch Foundation, Boeing-McDonnell Foundation, The Crawford Taylor Foundation, Daughters of Charity Foundation, Deer Creek Foundation, Emerson Charitable Trust, Employees Community Fund of Boeing-St. Louis, James S. McDonnell Foundation, Lutheran Foundation of St. Louis, Monsanto Fund, National Children's Cancer Society, Inc., and the St. Louis Cardinals Community Fund.The charities and grantmakers mentioned in this statement are just examples of the thousands of American NGO's endeavoring to improve the lives of others both at home and abroad.Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to reflect on the hard work and dedication of so many who take to heart the words of Scripture, ``It is more blessed to give than to receive'' (Acts 20:35). It is with admiration and respect that I commend the charitable community for stepping in to provide aid to the most vulnerable among us.

created_at: I rise today to introduce the Pension Opportunities for Women's Equality in Retirement (POWER) Act of 2000. This legislation is important because the current tax code often fails to give women--especially women who take time off to raise children--sufficient opportunities to earn a large enough pension to guarantee their financial security in retirement.The facts demonstrate that women need help in building pensions for their future. In America today
updated_at: two-thirds of women over 65 have no pension other than Social Security. This translates into 300
chamber: 000 women in my home state of Missouri and 14 million women nationwide. At the same time
title: the median income from assets for women age 65 and over is only $860 a year. Retirement is often compared to a three-legged stool
date: with the three legs being pensions
origin_url: savings
number: and Social Security. Now
order: everyone knows what happens to a three legged stool when one of the legs is missing: it falls over. But these statistics shows that many

column83: United States Code to provide for realignment of the Department of Defense workforce; to the Committee on Governmental Affairs.the department of defense civilian workforce realignment act of 2000Mr. President
column84: the Federal Government is facing a little-known
column85: yet serious problem that jeopardizes its ability to provide services to the American people--a crisis in human capital. The federal workforce has endured years of downsizing
column86: hiring freezes
column87: and inadequate investment in the dedicated men and women who comprise the federal civil service. As a result
column88: the Federal Government is ill-equipped to compete with the private sector for a new generation of technology-savvy workers to replace the nearly 900
column89: 000 ``baby boomers'' who will be eligible for retirement from the civil service in the next 5 years.To meet that challenge
column90: I rise today to introduce legislation
column91: along with my friend and colleague from Ohio
column92: Senator Mike DeWine
column93: that will help one critical department of our Federal Government--the Department of Defense--get a head start in addressing its future workforce needs. Our bill
column94: the ``Department of Defense Civilian Workforce Realignment Act of 2000
column95: '' provides the Department of Defense with greater flexibility to adequately manage its civilian workforce and align its human capital to meet the demands of the post-cold-war environment.During the last decade
column96: the Department of Defense underwent a massive civilian workforce downsizing program that saw a cut of more than 280
column97: 000 positions. In addition
column98: the Defense Department--like other federal departments--was subject to hiring restrictions. Taken together
column99: these two factors have inhibited the development of mid-level career
column100: civilian professionals; the men and women who serve a vital role in the management and development of our nation's military. The extent of this problem is exhibited in the fact that right now
column101: the Department is seriously understaffed in certain key occupations
column102: such as computer experts and foreign language specialists. The lack of such professionals has the potential to affect the Defense Department's ability to respond effectively and rapidly to military threats to our nation.The need to address the pending human capital crisis in the federal workforce is increasingly apparent
column103: as more and more leaders acknowledge that our past policies did not consider future federal workforce needs. Indeed
column104: in testimony before the Oversight of Government Management Subcommittee
column106: the head of the General Accounting Office
column109: ``(I)n cutting back on the hiring of new staff in order to reduce the number of their employees
column110: agencies also reduced the influx of new people with the new competencies needed to sustain excellence.''The bill that Senator DeWine and I are introducing today will help respond to these concerns by giving the Department of Defense the assistance it needs to shape the ``skills mix'' of the current workforce in order to address shortfalls brought about by years of downsizing. Our bill will also help the Department meet its needs for new skills in emerging technological and professional areas.Another area of concern for the Department of Defense--as well as many other federal agencies--is the serious demographic challenges that exist in its workforce. The average Defense Department employee is 45 years old
column111: and more than a third of the Department's workforce is age 51 or older. In the Department of the Air Force
column112: for example
column113: 45 percent of the workforce will be eligible for either regular retirement or early retirement by 2005.Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton
column114: OH
column115: is an excellent example of the demographic challenge facing military installations across the country. Wright-Patterson is the headquarters of the Air Force Materiel Command
column117: 700 civilian federal workers. By 2005
column118: 60 percent of the Base's civilian workforce will be eligible for either regular retirement or early retirement. Although a mass exodus of all retirement-eligible employees is not anticipated
column119: there is a genuine concern that a significant portion of the Wright-Patterson civilian workforce
column120: including hundreds of key leaders and employees with crucial expertise
column121: could decide to retire
column122: leaving the remaining workforce without experienced leadership and absent essential institutional knowledge.This combination of factors poses a serious challenge to the long-term effectiveness of the civilian component of the Defense Department
column123: and by implication
column124: the national security of the United States.Military base leaders
column125: and indeed the entire Defense establishment
column126: need to be given the flexibility to hire new employees so they can begin to develop another generation of civilian leaders and employees who will be able to provide critical support to our men and women in uniform.That is the purpose of the legislation we are introducing today. The Department of Defense Civilian Workforce Realignment Act addresses the current imbalance between the federal workforce and the skills needed to run the Federal Government in the 21st century
column127: as well as the age imbalance between new employees and the potential mass retirement of senior public employees in the next 5 years. If we wait for this ``retirement bubble'' to burst before we begin to hire new employees
column128: then not only will we be woefully understaffed in a number of key areas
column129: but we will have fewer seasoned individuals left in the federal workforce who can provide training and mentoring.The provisions in our bill will allow the Defense Department to conduct a smoother transition by bringing new employees into the Department over the next 5 years. The new employees will have the opportunity to work with and learn from their more experienced colleagues
column130: and invaluable institutional knowledge will be passed along.While this proposal does not address all of the human capital needs of the Defense Department
column131: it will help ensure that the Department of Defense recruits and retains a quality civilian workforce so that our Armed Forces may remain the best in the world. It is extremely important to the future vitality of the Department's civilian workforce and the national security of the United States that we address the human capital crisis while we have the opportunity. I urge my colleagues to support this legislation.Thank you

title: Missouri. I submit his speech for the Record:Congressman Skelton--thank you for that generous introduction. It's good to be here with you this evening-- thanks also for your service to our nation and the Army as the ranking member of the House Armed Services Committee. Your commitment to the national defense and your passion for the well-being of our men and women is legendary. We are indebted to you. Ladies and gentlemen--please join me in thanking Congressman Ike Skelton for his devotion to the soldiers
date: civilians
origin_url: and family members of the Army. In this room this evening are also some other patriots who have been great supporters of our military and our veterans. Many have served our nation in war; among their numbers are those who have felt the sting of battle. But all have provided our communities the kind of leadership that has made this country what it is today. To the Kansas City Chapter of the Military Order of the World Wars
number: thank you for your support of our soldiers and veterans. You know
order: this country enjoys a unique status in the community of nations. We are a great nation
volume: and we enjoy a vibrant and flourishing economy. No other nation enjoys our unique status in the way that we do today. Americans enjoy these special circumstances
pages: but many do not associate our national strength and our economic health with the readiness and professionalism of our military forces. The fact is
bioguide_id: however
speaker_raw: that you don't get to be a great power with the world's leading economy without also having a world class military that is respected by our allies and feared by our adversaries. Our military forces enable the great nation status enjoyed by the American people. No one understands or appreciates the importance of that link better than those who have defended this wonderful country of ours in war or those who have the responsibility of assuring the readiness of its military capabilities on a daily basis. The Military Order of the World Wars understands that linkage. Congressman Skelton understands that linkage. Both have worked to help us stay connected to the American people. They have helped us fill our ranks with the kind of youngsters who have kept our Army a force for good and an instrument of national policy. Again
column19: we are grateful for all that you do on our behalf. Also present in the room this evening are a very special group of international fellows. They are students at Fort Leavenworth who will spend the next year at the Command and General Staff College studying with

column22: all of the wars we have fought and most of our significant operational deployments have seen Americans serving side-by-side with soldiers from allied nations. We will never again fight on our own. Coalition and multinational operations are a fact of life. Many of the uniforms on display this evening are the ones who have shared space on distant battlefields with us. We are honored to have so many allied officers and their spouses here this evening. We know the keenness of the selection process that went on in each of your countries
column23: we are honored to have you join us in residence at Fort Leavenworth. You add to the education of our officers. Buffalo wings. There is a lot of excitement in and about our Army today. Many of you know that we have set a course to transform this great and magnificent army of ours from its current cold war designs to a force that is more responsive
